text: China reports its slowest growth rate
for nearly three decades trade war with
America doesn't mean for the rest of the
world China has been the economic
miracle of recent decades but is it
running out of steam and why does this
matter for the rest of us let's just
rewind China's economy is 42 times
larger than it was in 1980 the country
relied on cheap plentiful labor to
become the largest manufacturer and
exporter of goods on the planet
accounting for 1/5 of global trade but
growth has shifted down again the
officials figures say the economy is
growing by about six point six percent
but independent economists think it may
be closer to five percent or even lower
whatever the true figure 2018 was
China's weakest year since 1990 but why
well as the country flourished so too
did the wages of its workers so it lost
as competitive edge to the likes of
Vietnam the Philippines and Bangladesh
to counter its reliance with exports
China is not focusing on its home market
which means part of the slowdown is
intentional
another reason is the size of China's
debt borrowing by the government
companies and consumers now totals
almost three times the size of the
country's annual income the measures
imposed by the government to curb
lending have hit spending and investment
feeding into the slowdown all of this
has led to plenty of red lights flashing
when it comes to the country's
like health so what does the slowdown
look like inside China let's start with
manufacturing activity in that crucial
sector which makes up two fifths of the
economy contracted for the first time in
two years in December
then there's raw material prices as the
world's Factory China dictates the price
of many industrial metals and other
commodities some of those prices are
falling as demand wanes households are
feeling the squeeze their spending is
going up by less retail sales are
expanding at first lowest rate in 15
years even car sales are falling for the
first time in two decades and although
such numbers should always be treated
with caution investors are worried
shanghai stock market lost a quarter of
its value in 2018 and let's not forget
the trade war with the US which
triggered tariffs on both sides while
its impact so far has been limited the
threat of escalation remains a serious
risk not just a Chinese but world trade
growth and this is the crucial point any
slowdown in China's economy will have
repercussions for countries across the
world if Chinese consumers and companies
are not buying as much as previously
hoped so or doom and gloom well China's
time in the Sun its superhuman growth
spurt may be over by 2030
economists say growth will have settled
down to about a third of its current
value but even that would be enough to
ensure it overtakes the u.s. to take
pole position as the world's largest
economy
